Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Seating Solution for Improved Blood Flow
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to potentially provide a solution that will enable the furniture industry to address the issue of blood flow associated with prolonged sitting. The commercialization of the technology will potentially impact the lives of individuals who sit for prolonged periods of time, especially in the office work environment. This technology will steer the industry in a new direction using science and technology to address an important issue -- venous blood flow issue resulting from prolonged sitting.

This I-Corps project further develops a seating solution to address the issue of blood flow associated with prolonged sitting. Millions of individuals work in office and administrative support occupations. Most of these individuals spend majority of their working time sitting. With prolonged sitting there is immobility in the lower extremities which could result in venous blood flow issues and in some cases pulmonary embolism. The innovation is a seating solution with a seat that is split so there are two parts on the bottom that could move separately by pushing down on a lever and individuals could move their legs up and down. This proposed technology is valuable to any organization where individuals sit and work because of improved blood flow and perceived comfort which lead to greater satisfaction and increased productivity in work.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
TEAM moveSIT #1511

FINAL OUTCOME

Though a start-up was not formed by the Entrepreneurial Lead (EL), the Principal Investigator (PI) or the Co-Principal Investigator (Co-PI) while partnering with the Industry Mentor at the end of the National Science Foundation (NSF) I-Corps program to create a startup to make and sell moveSIT, a seating solution to help improve blood flow, they continue to explore business ideas to pursue. The EL is currently employed as an Assistant Professor in Illinois State University and the Co-PI moved to Penn State University. It is the expectation that the team will explore future collaborations and at the same time mentor future students at each of their institutions to explore the I-Corps program. The PI continues to work at Oklahoma State University (OSU) and intends to explore the possibility of developing moveCOMP, a smart compression wrap that can provide variable compression at different locations on the leg, feet and ankle, which can be used especially by older individuals who have blood flow issues. The PI has discussed this idea with two other functional apparel designer professors with backgrounds in Physics and Engineering and hopes to form a new team to pursue this idea in the future. The PI will also continue to work with IM and seek her industry experience as a similar solution to address blood flow issues is explored in the future. The PI has also integrated the business model canvas in his Problem Solving Class, which is a required class for all Interior Design, Apparel Design and Merchandising students in the program.

LESSONS LEARNED

The National I-Corps program felt like a boot camp. The team quickly learned that having a concept called moveSIT, a seating solution to help improve blood flow was not enough by itself, but exploring the value proposition for different potential customer segments was vital. The initial three-day workshop helped set the stage for the program, with the 15 interviews carried out then. After that having specific lesson plans centered around channels, revenue streams, key partners, activities and resources, and customer relationships while watching the Udacity videos and reading the two books (The Startup Owner’s Manual and especially the Business Model Generation) over the next few weeks while in parallel conducting interviews each week kept the team continually engaged while exploring different aspects of creating a startup. So, it was theory to practice each week. The importance of our instructors (Aaron Crum, Beth Kahn, Nancy Saucier, Kerry Bowie, Karen Golmer and Steve Kelly) cannot be emphasized enough. Having this group of instructors was the best thing that could have happened as it relates to our experience with the national program.

The second-best thing was learning from the other teams who participated in the program. Each idea presented by a team would make you pause and think about your total obtainable market (TOM) or your total value life-time cost (TVLC), your customer segments --- every part of your business canvas model. Who would have never thought of a smart bruxing device? The diversity in ideas gets you excited in terms of wanting to innovate. It was very interesting having not only teams from various parts of the United States, but internationally also. Also, each week listening to other teams and how they progressed with their interviews and what they learned helped us in the learning process. The process was very organic and the PI has adopted this technique in his classroom. Students are required to prepare prior to class and then come to class and teach while posing questions to other teams and then answering questions. In terms of future direction for the I-Corps program, it could be a good learning experience to conduct a 1-year follow up Skype session to see what the other teams in the cohort are doing.  

FUTURE DIRECTION

In terms of future direction, exploring the issue of blood flow continues to be an ongoing exploration. The decision to move away from a furniture solution and pursue an apparel solution that provides variable compression at various locations of the lower limbs through the use of piezo fibers and integration of remote sensors to control the variable compression using an app while to provide feedback appears to be promising. There is more potential for this idea to be classified as a medical device than a seating solution that helps improve blood flow. From the customer discovery process, it was determined that having moving parts in furniture could also become a liability issue. Thus, with a new team, the PI would like to potentially develop moveCOMP, a smart compression wrap that helps improve blood flow by 20% and thereby reducing the likelihood of developing blood clots, deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism.


Last Modified: 04/03/2020
Modified by: Aditya Jayadas
